Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE SITUATION ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Military personnel are standing and sitting around the table. Leo enters.

Dialogues.Line: Are we patched into the Pentagon?
Yeah.
Can we hear them?
Yeah.
We can hear what they're saying at command?
Yeah. Leo looks around the room impatiently.
Why can't I hear anything? An officer holds up hand in a 'wait' gesture.
Guys, why aren't we hearing anything?
[on radio] 1.2 seconds to target launch...
Okay, why don't you just tell me to shut up?
[on radio] We have a target launch sequence.
[on radio] Go flight.
[on radio] Kwajalein Atoll, how do you read?
[on radio] We read you 5 by 5, command. Positive target launch sequence.
Here we go.
[on radio] Target launch in 5, 4, 3, 2... Target is aloft.
[on radio] We confirm target launch.
How long do we have?
Two minutes, ten seconds.
[looks at his watch] I'm going to see if I can get the President to watch this. [leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: The President and the next Thailand Ambassador and his family are inside.

Dialogues.Line: Mr. Sumatra, I understand you're a sports fan.
Yes, sir, Mr. President. Golf.
Okay. Well, golf's not a sport. It's fine. Don't get me wrong but let's not you and I confuse it with things that men do.
[smiling] Yes, sir.
You know, we're going to Bangkok in June, I think. [to Charlie] June, Charlie?
[checks his palm pilot] Yes, sir.
You're staying at the Oriental?
Best hotel in the world, right?
Your own James Michener wrote many of his books at the Oriental and one of his typewriters remains in the suite they named for him.
Is that right?
Yes, sir.
[to Charlie] Make sure I see that.
Yes, sir.
[to diplomatic aide] Tom?

Mr. President, it is with great pleasure that I present his excellency, Tada Sumatra of Thailand and by request of the secretary of state ask that you accept his credentials from King Rhumibol Adulyadej [Bartlet accepts the papers from Sumatra.] as Thailand's ambassador to the United States.

Mr. Sumatra, I accept your letter of credence from King Adulyadej and by affixing my signature and seal, [signs the paper] do hereby declare you to be an ambassador extraordinary and plenipotentiary. [Sumatra bows and accepts the credentials back.] May our people know peace and prosperity. [They shake hands.] Congratulations.
Thank you, Mr. President.
We've some gifts here and we're going to stand for pictures.
[directing Sumatra] Ambassador, right here. Sumatra's wife joins them for the photographs.
[to Mrs. Sumatra] Madam, congratulations.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Charlie enters.

Dialogues.Line: He's got another two minutes and then I've got to pull him.
Okay.
[enters] Hey, Charlie, is he done?
He's got about another two minutes.
I'd like him in the situation room. Can I pull him?
Should I tell him it's an emergency?
It's not an emergency, just time sensitive.
Okay. [walks into the Oval Office]
[to Mrs. Landingham] What are you looking at?
You're testing that preposterous contraption again.
It's not preposterous. It's not a contraption and mind your own business.
In my day, we knew how to take care of ourselves.
Well, in your day, you could pretty much turn back the Indians with a Daniel Boone musket, couldn't you?
Ah, sarcasm. The grumpy man's wit.
Sharpen a pencil, would ya?
[enters from Oval Office] What's up?
The target's in the air. They're going to launch the intercept any moment.
And I'm sure someone will come along soon thereafter and tell it didn't work.
Why do you gotta take that attitude?
Cause it's not going to work.
What do I get if it works?
What do you get?
Yes.
Well, I can't make you Thailand's ambassador to the United States because I just signed that guy's letter. [points to Oval Office]
Come with me to the situation room. Leo turns to leave. Bartlet looks skeptically at Mrs. Landingham, then follows Leo downstairs.
You know what you are? You are the Charlie Brown of missile defense. The Pentagon is Lucy.
I'm not familiar with the reference.
Peanuts. Charlie Brown.
I've heard of them. I'm just not conversant in them.
Why?
I've never read the comics.
Leo, were you born at age 55?
I know there's a dog.
Charlie Brown wanted to kick a football and Lucy would hold it, except she'd pull it away at the last minute and Charlie Brown would fall on his butt.
That's funny?
No, but each time Lucy would find a way to convince Charlie Brown that this time she wouldn't pull the ball away. But she would and, once again, Charlie Brown would fall on his butt.
And that's funny?
Its' satirical.
What's it satirizing?
The DOD bringing you to the Situation Room every time they run a new missile test so that you come to me and tell me how great it works so I'll put money in the NMD system.
You should put money in the NMD system.
It doesn't work.
It will work. One day soon.
There're a couple of three star generals in there. Call any of 'em Lucy and you're on your own. They enter THE SITUATION ROOM.
Hey, where are we?
The kill vehicle is on a clear trajectory.
What's the time to the target.
Fifty seconds. Colonel, could you walk the President through?
Yes, sir. Mr. President, approximately 3 minutes, a missile was launched with a simulated nuclear warhead from the Kwajalein Atoll in the South Pacific.
And it's going to hit my garage in New Hampshire when?
Well, sir, once the missile cleared cloud cover, it was detected by the early warning satellites, which launched an interceptor, or kill vehicle.
[on radio] 10 seconds to SRB separation.
SRB separation is solid rocket boosters separation. That means a high-resolution radar on the ground has gotten a lock on signal from the kill vehicle.
[on radio] Go SRB separation.
[on radio] Confirm solid rocket booster separation.
[on radio] Kill vehicle's away. Coming over a 044.
[on radio] 20 seconds to target intercept.
[on radio] Go flight.
So what happens now?
In 20 seconds, it collides with the nuclear warhead.
Where?
Outer space.
17 miles above the earth's atmosphere.
Okay, but we don't have anybody out there right now do we?
Sir...
When we stay at the Oriental in Bangkok, we have to check out Michener's typewriter.
[on radio] Intercept in 5, 4...
Here we go.
[on radio] 3, 2, 1. Silence. As everyone hangs their heads, an officer sighs.
Is that silence a pretty good sign?
No.
[on radio] Negative intercept.
Have we got sensor readings yet?
No.
[on radio] Negative intercept. KM warhead has overshot it's target.
It was just enthusiastic.
By how much?
Uh, Leo...
[sternly] By how much did it miss the target?
Colonel?
We missed the target by 137 feet?
Miles.
[looks at him, incredulous] We missed it by 137 miles?!
When you consider the size of outer space, Leo, that's not so bad.
Sir?
By the way, the words you're looking for are "Oh good grief." [walks out]

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - DAY
Scenes.Description: An aerial view of outside of White House.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE BRIEFING ROOM - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: C.J. is on the podium.

Dialogues.Line: For those of you who haven't seen it, it's a very lovely ceremony. It's relatively informal, the ambassadors are led into the Oval Office, probably with a few friends and family. They chat for a few moments with President, maybe exchange some gifts, and they're officially presented by the State Department's Chief of Protocol, who asks the President to accept the ambassador's credentials and the President signs a letter to that effect. [points to a reporter] Yes?
C.J., you're accepting four new ambassadors this week. Is there an order or protocol in which they're seen?

There is! It's the order in which they arrived in Washington. This morning the President saw Ambassador Sumatra of Thailand, then will be Peter Hans of Sweden, followed by her Excellency Renee Ernesto of Argentina, Noah Jolla of Burkina Faso and the newly named British Ambassador to the United States will be arriving in the United States just as soon as he's been newly named.
I thought it was gonna be...
Yeah.
I forgot his name...
Anthony Brass.
Yeah.
Anthony Brass cited family obligations at home, and withdrew his name over the weekend.
Yeah, but weren't they gonna replace him with...
Sir Christopher Nealingroach, yes. Sir Christopher has been diagnosed with a rare form of encephalitis, contracted during his recent posting to Kenya.
So who's the new British ambassador?

I don't know. As soon as the State Department tells me, I'll know. In the meantime, it's pool photographs only until tomorrow night when there'll be a cocktail reception for the new ambassadors. That's all. [Reporters get up and leave] Does anybody wanna know who's been here the longest? The Dean of the Diplomatic Corps...anybody? Guys, you know I study these things just for you! It's Prince Vandaar Ben Sultan of Saudi Arabia.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: C.J. is talking to Carol.

Dialogues.Line: I could have also told them that Burkina Faso has a population of eleven million and in even years they host Africa's largest crops market. CAROL: Yes.
I need a chance to use that knowledge.
[comes up from behind] C.J.! C.J. passes paper to Carol, who leaves. Sam walks with C.J.
You know the chief crops of Burkina Faso?
No.
Millet, sorghum, rice, peanuts and cotton.
[beat] You should mention in your afternoon briefing that we've accepted a last minute invitation for the President to address the Global Defense Council tomorrow night at the Sheraton.
I thought we passed on the GDC.

Well we passed on it three months ago when we thought the President was going to be in South America. But the trip got canceled and they lost their keynote speaker, so we're gonna use this to launch CARE, and that's what I want you to announce at the afternoon briefing.
CARE?
Yeah.
Ok...
Clean Air Rehabilitation Effort.
Yeah.
You don't know what it is.
It's an effort by which we clean the air and rehabilitate it.
Okay, how could you...
I'm not involved in the nuances of environmental policy!
Which will come as a relief to environmentalists.
Sam!
I'll brief you later.
I knew the crops of Burkina Faso!
I'll brief you later. Sam leaves C.J. and walks into THE ROOSEVELT ROOM. Bonnie, Ginger, and several other people are seated around the table with notepads and laptops.
Have we heard from Toby?
No.
Do we know if he's landed?
No.
How is everyone doing in here?
They're doing fine.

Is global warming a real environmental condition, or merely a temporary anomaly? Is it a global threat, or the exaggerated claim of alarmists? The time for such debate is over. As of today, it shall be the unequivocal position of the United States government that global warming constitutes a clear and present danger to the health and future well-being of this planet and all its inhabitants. Did somebody get that?
Yes.
I didn't see anyone writing.
We already wrote it.
I just added a thing!
We got it.
I just added "the time for such debate is over."
We got it!
It sets up the whole reveal.
Yes.
Okay. 22 trillion in benefits versus one half a trillion in compliance costs we're making sure that's right?
Yes.
We're making sure in a couple places?
They're making sure.
I wanna cite three different sources.
Fine.
And we don't know if Toby's back?
Sam! You'll know as soon as he's back! Toby walks in in a coat and carrying luggage.
[holding a cell phone] Sam...
Is it Toby? GINGER: Yeah...
Can I have the phone?
[points] He's standing right there. Sam turns and sees Toby in the HALLWAY.
Thanks. 22,000 fewer respiratory related hospital admissions? I don't wanna use the stats unless I have three sources. [walks over to Toby] How was your trip?
It was fine. [clears throat] What's goin' on?
The President's gonna speak at the GDC conference tomorrow night.
I'm sorry?
He's gonna launch the...
What are you talking about?
He's gonna launch CARE.
Since when?
Their keynote speaker fell through.
When was this decision made?
Last night.
Why wasn't I involved?
You were in Kansas City.
I have a telephone.
Toby!
I have a damn telephone Sam!
Frankly, I didn't think... I thought there'd be a consensus.
Who was at this meeting?
It was me, Carl Todd of the EPA, James Siskin was there... Toby we've been looking for an opportunity to launch...
Leo wasn't there?
No... been looking for a platform for this, the opportunity...
Let me understand...
...presented itself. What's the problem? They go into TOBY'S OFFICE.

There are a number of problems, anyone of which I could have told you about, had you gotten me on the phone! Well, one thing, we already blew off the AFL CIO, cause we told them the President was gonna be in South America.
The President was gonna be in South America, now he's not.
Instead, he's speaking for labor's good friend, the environmental lobby!
No...
Also, he's the President of the United States, he's nobody's understudy! You've got him goin' out there like... Joey Bishop!
I gotta say, I hear all that, but the President, he's very enthusiastic.
Of course he's enthusiastic.

I'm sayin', I wasn't in there twisting his arm! I told him this opportunity has opened up, that we had enough notes so that I could finish the speech in time. He asked us a few questions, we answered them and he said yes!
Alright... I don't... alright.
It's gonna be a good speech!
Yeah.
[enters] They need you.
Thanks. [leaves]
How was the trip?
Fine. I need to see Leo.
Yeah. Ginger leaves as Toby picks up the phone.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Josh is standing against the wall by the door, while talking to C.J. on the speaker phone.

Dialogues.Line: It's not gonna be Sir Christopher Nealingroach.
[sounding strained] I heard!
I said it's not gonna be Sir Christopher Nealingroach.
And I said I heard you!

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: But I like to say Sir Christopher Nealingroach.
Who's it gonna be?
I'm waiting to hear from someone at the State Department.
Me too.
Maybe it'll be Sir Christopher Nealingroach.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: Can I stop talking to you now?
What are you doing?
I'm standing with my back straight against the wall.
Why?
I was told by the doctors it would relax me. The door opens. Donna enters and hits Josh with the door.
Josh... [turns and sees him behind the door]
Gotta go! [hangs up]
Yeah.
Are you ok?
Yeah. What?
Is it true that Leo can't stand a guy named Lord John Marbury?
Why?
A reporter asked me.
What's a reporter doing talking to you?
He's a friend of a friend.
Leo McGarry has nothing but respect and affection for John Marbury.
That's what I said.
Good, 'cause Leo thinks he's a lunatic.
He's very handsome.
That may be so, but Leo thinks he's a lunatic.
Are you threatened by his brilliance?
No.
You seem to be threatened by his brilliance.
How do you know he's brilliant?
I saw his picture.
I'm not threatened by his brilliance, nor am I threatened by his good looks.
What about his charm?
I'm not threatened at all...
I'm sorry, I meant Leo.
Neither Leo or I are threatened by his brains, his looks or his charm. He is, however, a lunatic Brit and we're grateful there's an ocean between us.
There isn't anymore.
There isn't what?
An ocean between you.
Please, don't tell me...
He's the new British ambassador to the United States.
[sounding strained again] Yeah... [gets up]
He's dreamy. [walks over to the door]
I'm just gonna, you know, stand next to the wall for a while longer.
Okay. She throws the door open, which slams into the wall very close to him, and leaves. Josh groans.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Josh is sitting at his desk while Toby knocks on the door and enters.

Dialogues.Line: Josh.
Okay, what I need people to do is knock.
I did knock.
But you didn't wait for a response.
Why would I?
'Cause, I could have been relaxing by standing behind that door.
[beat] All right.
How was your trip? They walk out of the office and head through JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA.
It was fine. So we're pitchhitting at the GDC conference.
For the record, I didn't think it was a good idea and I said so.
And it seems to have helped. Look, we can't appear to be at the beckon call of the environment!
We could try insulting them.
Yes.
I'm kidding.
I'm not!
What do you have?
Environmental terrorists burned down a ski resort and the GDC didn't comment.
Why did environmental terrorists burn down a ski resort?
To save the lynx.
The links?
Yeah.
Environmental terrorists burned down a ski resort to save a golf course?
It's an animal.
Sam's going to have strong objections.
I know.
All right, you want me to talk to Leo?
I'm going to talk to him. I want you to talk to C.J..
About what?
The Will Roger's dinner is going to ask Cornelius Sykes to host.
[stops and faces Toby] You're kidding me!
Nope.
He didn't laugh at the joke.
Talk to C.J.
Yeah. [turns away to leave]
Why do you relax by standing behind the door?
[comes back] I'm not standing behind the door, I'm standing with my back straight against the wall, so that if...
I don't care. [leaves abruptly]
'kay.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Leo is talking on the phone, while Toby enters.

Dialogues.Line: Keith. Keith, I can't tell him that. I can't tell the President that nine out of ten things went right, he's going to say, "Yeah, but we didn't hit anything!" Would you please? Thank you. [hangs up the phone, to Toby] We had an NMD test this morning. We were successful in nine out of ten criteria.
We missed.
Yeah.
By how much?
We were trying to shoot down an incoming intercontinental ballistic missile; once you miss, it really doesn't matter by how much.
I suppose.
A hundred and thirty-seven miles.
[rolls his eyes] Sam just told me about his speech.
Which speech?
The GDC.
Yeah.
Leo.
[defensively] I wasn't in the meeting.
How did that...
I wasn't in the meeting! It happened fast.
I'm saying how'd it...
It happened fast. Sam pitched it, and the President wanted to do it.
Leo, how could you not be in that meeting?
'Cause I'm trying to get the President to warm up to a missile shield that's supposed to save humanity and there's a limit to the number of rooms I can be in at once! You want to file a complaint?
No.
Good.
Here's what I think...
Screw the environmental lobby?
[angry] Did I say that? Did I say, 'screw the environmental lobby?'
You didn't say anything.
That's right, and before I even open my mouth, you decide I'm going to say 'screw the environmental lobby?'
I apologize.
There's an extent to which we've gotta screw the environmental lobby.
Yep.
A clear and public demonstration that the President's not beholden to them isn't a bad idea right now.
You think he should walk into their ballroom and smack them around?
I really do, for thirty seconds out of a fortyminute address announcing the initiative they love.
How do you think they're gonna feel about the 30 seconds?
Not that good, but that's the point. We don't have to move to our right if there's an opportunity to spank the people to our left.
Anything in particular we want to spank them for?
Failing to publicly admonish acts of eco-terrorism.
The GDC doesn't engage in acts of eco-terrorism.
Yes, but they fail to publicly admonish those who do.
For example?
A 12 million dollar Colorado ski development that was under construction was set on fire because it threatened the habitat of a rare local lynx.
Is a lynx a...?
I don't know. I... I think... I think it's like a possum or something, and it doesn't matter...
All right, tell Sam to find a place to out it.
I don't want it in the advanced text. I don't want Sam and his fourteen objections. It should just be a drop-in.
I'll talk to the President. Anything else?
137 miles.
Yeah.
Is that a lot?
Yeah.
Okay. [leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE PRESS ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. is sitting in the first row, a few reporters with notes behind her, Sam is perched on the windowsill. They are going over his speech.

Dialogues.Line: We have 30 minutes at the ballroom after the speech to spin and obviously, the next morning as well. Among the things you want to be emphasizing are what?
[chewing a sandwich] America is the world's biggest emitter of carbon dioxide.
We have 4% of the population. We are responsible for 25% of the Greenhouse emission. [stands] How are we going to reduce those levels of Greenhouse emissions, you ask?
Through the Clean Air Rehabilitation Effort.
Yes, which you can read about in bullet points, beginning on page 11. Please don't skip the footnotes, and please, don't just read what's underlined. The reporters sigh. Sam munches on a baby carrot.
Question.
[chewing] Yes.
Were you able to get girls to go out with you in High School?
Yes.
Really?
[returns to the windowsill] Under these regulations there will be a cap on the volume of CO2 a company could emit in a year, but what's the good news?
If the company comes in lower than the cap, they could sell the balance of their emissions allowance to another company.
Creating what? REPORTERS 1 & 2 A cash incentive!
A cash incentive. Can you tell us anything else about that, C.J.?
No, but I can tell you that lumber, cocoa beans, aluminum and petroleum products are the major exports of Cameroon. Sam stares at her. Josh opens the door and peeks in.
[shocked by C.J.'s lack of caring] Then we're all set.
Yeah.
Can I have her for a second?
Yeah.
[to Josh] Why do you ask him and not me?
He looked in charge!
Of where I go?
Can we... please? C.J. and Josh walk outside and close the door.
Did you hear they named John Marbury British Ambassador?
Yes, I did.
Lord John Marbury?
I know, it's got to be like Davy Jones himself is showing up.

Ok, don't make fun of Davy Jones, all right? He once wrote me a letter. He took that kind of time. And he still tours! Plus, my love for John Marbury is real, it's not a schoolgirl crush. He calls me [gently] 'Princepessa.'
Does he?
Yeah.
Well, he calls Leo 'Gerald.'
He's eccentric.
Yeah.
What do you need?
Janice Barry is saying they're going to ask Cornelius Sykes to host the Will Rogers' dinner.
They know for sure?
They're going to ask him on Monday.
They're going to stir this up again.
Yeah.
He didn't laugh at the joke! How many more ways are there for me to say that? He didn't laugh at the joke!
You guys are friends. I was thinking...
We're not friends.
You know each other.
I don't hang out with Corey Sykes!
Yeah, but you know him!
[beat] Where is he?
He's in New York, doing standup. I thought since you were going to be there, you...
I'll see him tomorrow night.
Thank you. [turns to leave]
He didn't laugh at the joke!
[turns to her while walking away] You'll see him tomorrow night?
Yes. From offscreen right, Donna catches up with Josh.
Josh!
[walking backwards] Could you see that a meeting is arranged for tomorrow night in New York with C.J., Cornelius Sykes, and no one else?
Yeah. C.J., standing in front of the closed door of the Press Room, yells.
Thank you! Donna and Josh are walking through the HALLWAYS.
I was thinking...
Yeah?
When Marbury gets here...
Yeah?
You can encourage him to introduce me to any royal and single men he might know.
That's a good idea, I'm gonna do that.
You're not really though, are you?
No. Donna makes a pouting face, and they part.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Bartlet is accepting papers from the newly named ambassador of Sweden. The ambassador's wife and two children are in the room, so is the Presenter and a few men with cameras.

Dialogues.Line: I think a lot of people don't realize that Swedes have lived in Sweden more than 5,000 years longer than nearly any other European people.
That's right, sir.
In fact, Gothic tribes from Sweden played a major role in the disintegration of the Roman Empire, did they not?
They did.
So you've got that to answer for!
[smiling] Yes, sir! Bartlet laughs. Leo enters the office.

Mr. President, it is with pleasure that I present his Excellency Peter Hans of Sweden, and by request of the Secretary of State ask that you accept his credentials from king Karl Gustav as Sweden's ambassador to the United States.

[puts his eyeglasses on] Mr. Hans, I accept your letter of credence from king Gustav, and, by affixing my signature and seal, do hereby declare you to be an Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary. [returns the papers]
Thank you, Mr. President.
Congratulations. [They shake hands.]
Mr. Ambassador. [shows Hans to a spot next to Bartlet] Family, please. They pose for pictures. Leo shakes hands with Hans.
Congratulations, Ambassador.
Leo.
Is he still holding you responsible for the fall of the Roman Empire?
Oh, yes.
Welcome to my world. I'll see you at the reception, right?
Yes, sir.
Congratulations.
This way. The ambassador leaves with his family, everyone else exits.
Sweden has a 100% literacy rate, Leo, a hundred percent! How do they do that?
Well, maybe, they don't and they also can't count.
Maybe.
[hands him some papers] I really think you should know...
Yes?
That nine out of ten criterion that the DOD lays down for success in these tests were met.
The tenth being?
They missed the target.
[with sarcasm] Damn!
Sir!
So close.
Mr. President.
That tenth one! See, if there were just nine...
Look, the tracking software on the KM vehicle clearly acquired the read on both the target and the decoy. Charlie walks in and gives Bartlet a blue folder.
And, for the first time ever, successfully rendered a clean identification differential.
Leo, seriously, when they were telling you that on the phone, how stupid did you think you'd sound saying that to me?
This project needs money!
It doesn't work.
Neither did several phases of Apollo 11, but Neil Armstrong claims it was a success.
Do we have to decide this right now?
No.
Okay.
So, about the GDC speech...
[putting his glasses on and reading] Yeah?
Since we're giving them exactly what they want, Toby thinks it's not such a bad idea if we signal our independence as well.
How?
A drop-in. Eco-terrorism that's gone unadmonished by the GDC.
For example?
A ski development in Colorado that threatened a rare lynx was burned in protest.
And we can't take it for granted that everyone pretty much fundamentally opposes arson?
A year and a half ago you stood in the Mural Room and took Al Caldwell's head off because the Christian League hadn't publicly admonished religious extremists.
It would be hypocrisy not to hold our friends to the same standard...
Yes.
Yet it feels strange to score political points by doing the right thin.
Yeah.
[gruffly] I'm victim to my own purity of character.
Whatever. [beat] We'll get you some information on the lynx, which is a kind of a possum, I think.
Okay, well, it's not a kind of a possum, so why don't you get me that information. Toby doesn't want it in the speech?
Just the drop-in.
Did you hear?
About Marbury?
Ain't it great?
Yes, sir. And I assume you're enjoying my suffering?
Absolutely.
Anything else?
No.
Thank you, Mr. President. [walks out]
[shouts after him] 2,000 environmentalists are going to try and kill me tomorrow night! Charlie enters again.
We should go, sir.
They're going to come at me with vegan food and pitchforks!
[while they walk out] That doesn't really sound like something people do.
Still, I'd like you to get between me and any boiled seaweed you see coming my way.
Yep. Toby is waiting outside and walks with the President. Charlie is walking behind them.
Mr. President.
Leo has just talked to me.
About the GDC tonight.
Yeah, I'm not doing this for the politics, I'm doing it because it's the right thing to do.
Well, I'm doing it for the politics.
A lynx isn't a possum.
I think it's in the possum family.
It's a cat.
Oh, and we don't have enough of those. [Bartlet smiles.]
How did Sam feel about this? [beat] Toby?
This isn't government camp, it's not like... it's not important that everybody gets to play! They stop and face each other.
I'm not going to tell you how to run your office, Toby.
Thank you, sir.
[beat, resumes walking] Vegan food. Coming at me all night long. As they leave, Toby spots C.J. who is wearing her coat and has a briefcase.
C.J.?
Yeah.
Where are you going?
New York, New York, Toby. The town so nice they named it twice.
What are you doing there?
I'm receiving the Matrix Award from New York women in communications.
For what?
I discovered a comet. What do you mean, 'for what?' Past winners, by the way, include Cokie Roberts, Diane Sawyer and Ms. Leslie Stahl.
Josh talked to you about...
Yeah, I'm meeting him for a drink after the thing.
You briefed on the Clean Air Rehabilitation...?
Yeah.

Okay, you might need this: [reads from his pocketbook] 'The President has always spoken out against moderate groups not taking responsibility for extremism, and he isn't going to stop with the environmental lobby. Friends are honest with each other.' [hands C.J. the piece of paper he read from]
He's gonna do a drop-in?
Yeah.
I'll see you tomorrow night. [leaves] Bonnie opens the door next to which Toby is standing.
Hey, Toby, you want to see the speech? Sam's writing a good one. She gives him the copy of the speech. Toby looks over it.
Oh.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. SAM'S OFFICE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: [fixing his tie] Climate changes have accelerated. Glaciers are shrinking. Polar sea is... what?
[from communications office] It's thinning.
The polar sea ice is thinning causing a rise in sea levels round the globe.
And what do we say when they say, "But changes in the Clean Air Rehabilitation effort seriously choke the auto, trucking and utility business"?
[walks to Toby] $22 trillion in benefits produced versus a half trillion in compliance costs. [keeps walking past Toby]
Public health benefits?
We'll make that clear. [turns back to face Toby] Where's C.J.?
She's in New York.
What's she doing in New York?
She had a lunch - media women... women of media?
That was this afternoon.
She had to stay around.
So it's just me?
Yeah. Call me from the place.
Yeah. He walks out of bullpen and into THE ROOSEVELT ROOM and picks up a copy of the speech.
Well, it's the 12th draft. Whether or not it's the final draft is up to you.
Is that sass?
Yeah.

Okay. The difference between a good speech and a great speech is the energy with which the audience comes to their feet at the end. Is it polite? Is it a chore? Are they standing up because their boss is standing up? No, we want it to come from their socks. We've got a half an hour. Let's read it again.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Leo and Josh are inside.

Dialogues.Line: Every time one of these tests fails, congressional Democrats jump on it as a reason to kill the program.
You're not going to turn the President around on the missile shield.
Well, I'm not going to turn him around today. And probably not tomorrow. But as long as somebody has the money to keep trying to make it work, then I'm fine.
[walks in] Leo?
Yeah?
There's someone here to see you.
Who?
Gerald?
Oh, God.
[enters] Gerald! Old friend!
Good to see you, ambassador. They shake hands. Margaret leaves.
It's as if the gods themselves insist we be not long apart, you and I.
They do seem to strongly insist upon that, yes.
Your assistant, Margaret, is looking positively buxom.
Thank you, I'll tell her.
Thank you.
[turns in her direction] Yes, well done! [indicates a woman behind him] Oh, my aide, Caprice.
[shakes Leo's hand] How do you do?
Leo McGarry.
Good to see you, ambassador.
God bless you, Josh. The prayers of millions were answered.
[a little stunned] Thank you, sir.
I have come.
Yes.
I am Lord John Marbury, along with my aide, Caprice, and I am hereby presenting my credentials in the fervent hope...
John, we do that later with the President.
Excellent! [hands papers back to Caprice]
I will tell you, though, that I personally welcome you and I look forward to our new partnership.
As do I.
I know we've had our differences in the past but I think you know I respect you. I congratulate you on this auspicious occasion. As a matter of fact, the timing of your arrival couldn't be better.
How so?
Leo's trying to convince the president to give the NMD more time.
And you're an expert in the field. And I hope I can count on your support.
You may hope for it but you'll not have it.
Why not?

Because the NMD is an absurdly wasteful military boondoggle that will never produce a working missile. It violates any number of elements of the ABM treaty. And any argument you make in its defense will surely be moronic.
Ah, detente.
I'm sorry, Gerald.
We're going to have this out.
Excellent.
Let's go get you knighted or whatever the hell it is we do.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HOTEL LOBBY IN NEW YORK CITY - DAY
Scenes.Description: Cornelius Sykes is meeting with C.J.

Dialogues.Line: Hey.
Hey, how you doing?
Not bad.
Thanks for taking the time.
Yeah, I've gotta get back pretty soon.
I won't take long. [They sit.]
You wanna stay for the show?
I gotta get the 7:00 shuttle.
You want something to drink?
Uh, a club soda.
[to waitress] Alicia? Can I get a club soda?
Oh, I haven't seen the movie yet.
You should see it. It's good.
That's what everybody's saying.
Well, I appreciate that.
[laughs] So, you know, this is about the Will Rogers dinner.
Yeah.
They're going to ask you to host and obviously the President's going to be there. [beat] We appreciate the support.
You want me to say no.
We think the press'll go back two years and bring up the whole...
Let'em.
I don't want to. Uh, you know how I feel about you. You know I don't mean you disrespect.
You don't?
No!

I've raised money for you. I've registered voters for you. I've done commercials for you. And I voted for you. Because of something I never did wrong two years ago, you don't want to be on the dais with me?
That's not...
It takes a special kind of arrogance not to think that that's not disrespectful. The waitress puts their drinks on the table.
Thanks, Alicia. [to C.J.] Make your case. I've got to be funny in a while.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE MURAL ROOM - DAY

Dialogues.Line: It missed by 137 miles?!
Yes.
It could have missed by 37 fewer miles and it still would have missed by 100 miles. It doesn't work.
That depends on what your definition is.
My definition is precisely the same as everyone else's.
[walks in with Josh and Charlie] John!
Mr. President.
[shakes his hand] It's good to have you here.
Your servant, as always.
What made you decide to take the post?
Oh, I don't know. I suppose it was possible I was drunk.
Reasonable bet.
Listen, I gotta go a few blocks across town to give an address on global warming and the future of our planet. That's not something you're interested in, right?
Good God, no.
Okay. Well, stay here and fight with Leo about something. We'll get you some dinner. I'll be back in an hour. We'll do your thing and then enjoy your reception.
Excellent.
Indeed.
Here we go. Leo, Bartlet and Charlie leave.
An hour, did he say?
Yes.
I'll need some amusement.
[enters] Good evening, your lordship.
Excellent.

Dialogues.Character: CUT TO INT. HOTEL LOBBY IN NEW YORK CITY
Dialogues.Line: DAY
Corey...
Hang on.
No, wait a second...
Let me finish.
It was not a benign joke.
You don't tell benign jokes.
It's a matter of...
It was a joke about New York City cops shooting black men.
I'm a black man. I'm in a room full of rich Democrats in an election year. What you thought I was going to talk about airline food?
It was a political fundraiser in the heat of a national campaign. You weren't doing a 2 a.m. set at Catch a Rising Star.
[insulted] You know how many years it's been since I worked Catch a Rising Star?
You made the joke, and inoffensive as you think it may have been, there was enormous pressure on the candidate to disavow your remarks and he did not.
And I'm supposed to be...
Corey...
And I'm supposed to feel good about that? That he didn't disavow me? That I wasn't disavowed?
We were courting law enforcement, Corey. Don't be naive.
You were also courting the black vote, C.J.. I'm not naive.
What did you expect us to do?

I expected that when I was called, in any number of places, a Hollywood sleaze, that you might have said a few words, maybe, on my behalf. I expected that you were going to say, "We in the Bartlet campaign do not believe Cornelius Sykes is a Hollywood sleaze. We believe he's a world class humorist and millions of Americans agree. We believe his humor can be disconcerting to some but those who are making noise right now are feigning their concern in an effort to frighten white men." But what you said was, "He didn't laugh at the joke."
Corey...
He did laugh at the joke.
Yeah.

He laughed at the joke, C.J.. I've been doing this for 20 years. You don't think I'd know if I had him? I killed that night. That was a very big deal for me. To play in front of that audience? To get that man to laugh? And the next day my parents read in the paper that I am Hollywood sleaze. But that's okay cause the candidate didn't think it was funny.
[looking uncomfortable] I understand.

I don't want to cause any trouble for the President. You knew that when you walked in here. I'll pass on the dinner. I'll tell'em it's cause I can't get out of a booking. But the president laughed at the joke, C.J.. I killed that night.
[smiling] You did. Okay, I gotta go.
I'll see you next time.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Toby walks through.

Dialogues.Line: Is the President offstage yet?
Just about.
Anyone know how it's going?
Toby?
Yeah?
[holds up the phone] It's Sam.
Yeah. [walks into his office and picks up the phone] Yeah?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY IN THE SHERATON - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: The President finished his speech. Sam is standing near the door.

Dialogues.Line: [disappointed, into phone] He admonished them.
Sam...
He went off the speech right at the end and slapped them down for not speaking out...
Yeah.
...on eco-terrorism.
Listen.
He just flew off the speech.
Sam, listen.
Something about a Colorado ski resort.
Sam, are you listening?
Talk to me.

Here's what you say, "Friends are honest with each other. The President has always spoken out on moderate groups not taking responsibility for terrorism and he isn't going to stop with the environmental lobby."
Okay.
You got that?
Yeah.
[hears clapping] What's happening? [pause] Sam, what's happening?
[standing outside the room, his back to a wall, looking mournful] They're not standing.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. HALLWAY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Donna and Lord John Marbury are walking.

Dialogues.Line: So you're actual royalty?
Yes.
It's not just an honorary thing?
No, in fact there's little honor attached to it at all
Tell me about yourself.

Well, my mother was a descendant of the third of the nine children of Victoria. Victoria was the granddaughter of George the third, who was the great-grandson of George the first. George the first was the great-nephew of Charles the first, who was the son of James the first, and James' mother was Mary, Queen of Scots.
And are you and Caprice an item?
Why, no.
[walking up between them] Mr. Ambassador?
Is he back?
He's back, but he's receiving credentials from Her Excellency Renee Ernesto of Argentina and asked for your patience.
Then my patience he shall have! Sam walks by and catches up with C.J., who has just walked in, still in her hat and coat.
C.J.!
Yeah.
You just get back?
Yeah.
You heard what happened?

Yeah. Here's what it is: the President has always spoken out on moderate groups not taking responsibility for extremism, and he isn't going to stop at the environmental lobby. Friends are honest with each other. [as Sam stops walking] Sam?
Have you spoken to Toby?
When?
Since after the speech tonight
No.
Okay.
They're setting up for the reception?
Yeah.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Toby and Leo are inside.

Dialogues.Line: Sixty billion dollars can be spent on other things.
I'm all for retention pay. I'm all for health benefits. I'm all for procurement.
I'm talking about Abrams' tax and Apache helicopters, which we know work.
An Apache helicopter will not stop a Shahab3 longrange stiletto, or a North Korean ICBM. Sam passes by outside.
Well so far neither can anything else. [calling outside] Hey, Sam?
I'm going back in there. Toby walks out of office and up to Sam.
Have you been getting questions?
I'm sorry?
Have you been getting questions?
Yeah.
From the press, or...?
The press'll be tomorrow.
So who's asking?
The chairman of the GDC. Four Congressmen. The Secretary of the Interior. Who'd you think would be talking to me?
Then what did you...?

I said, "Sometimes friends have to be honest with each other." I said exactly what you told me to say, which, coincidentally, is exactly C.J. told me to say, which is remarkable when you consider that C.J. was in New York during the event and didn't speak to you afterward. I mean, it's almost as if there were people who knew it was going to happen.
Sam...
Get away from me. Sam walks out of office and to the OUTER OVAL OFFICE. He stands for a moment, then the door opens and Charlie walks out.
Hey, Sam.
Is it possible I could get in for just a minute? Toby appears in the hallway looking in. He shakes his head at Charlie.
He's pretty tight right now. I don't think I can get you in. Sam looks over his shoulder and spots Toby, who walks away. Sam gives Charlie a betrayed look, then leaves.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. RECEPTION HALL - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Music is playing. Donna and Marbury are chatting.

Dialogues.Line: Oh, well, yes. Oh, certainly. There's uh, Edward, Earl of Ulster. He's the son of Richard, Duke of Gloucester, who's the son of Henry, Duke of Gloucester.
Edward, Earl of Ulster?
Yes.
Do you think he'd like me?
Do you date younger men?
Sure. How old is he?
Five.
Okay, well let's stick a pin in that for a moment and move on. Leo walks up.
Hello.
Hello.
Am I interrupting?
Not at all.

Ambassador Marbury was just telling me about how royal men are schooled in the ways of courtship. King George III, for example, sailed his bride up the river Thames to music that was specially composed.
Yeah. That was just a few years before we opened up a big can of whoopass on him at Yorktown.
Leo, I- [as Donna slips away]
How can you look at North Korea, which 24 months ago fired a Taepodong missile...?
Uh, which failed...
And with some modifications it'll be able to reach Alaska.

Well I don't live in Alaska, I live in England, which by the way is not protected by the shield. Not that anywhere else is at the moment, either. You've also forgotten that we're both signatories to the '72 ABM treaty, which the shield is in clear violation. You've forgotten that it will compel China to strengthen their nuclear arsenal. You've forgotten that the European allies have strong reservations about the shield. And you've forgotten that it doesn't work.
You know what I haven't forgotten?
What?
That we opened up a big can of whoopass on you at Yorktown!
All right.
[coming up to them] Leo?
Excuse me.
Excuse me.
[passing by Charlie] I'm going to correspond with Edward, Earl of Ulster, once he learns how to read and write.
Okay.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WHITE HOUSE MESS - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam is having a drink. Alice, the waitress, comes up.

Dialogues.Line: Here you go.
No, no, Alice. I got it.
It's all right.
No, I got it.
You want a beer?
Yeah. Thanks. He hands her money, and she leaves.
You don't ever go into the Oval Office mad.
Look...
No, no, no. No, Sam. You don't ever go in there mad
I think the President's remarks were ill advised, to say the least.
You're wrong.
The drop-in's the story now, Toby, not the energy package.
The energy package doesn't need to be a story; it's going to be a law.
You don't think we're going to need the environmental lobby?
I think we need them, I just don't think we're going to lose them.
And I think you're tragically misguided.
Sam...
Many, if not most, environmentalists are absolutists who will use this insult to pull their support under cover we cut a deal in Detroit.
Well then they can grow up, Sam. Use this insult? They just got the energy package they wanted, they just got the president at their dinner, and they should shut up!
Well you should explain it to them just that way, Toby, cause they're really pretty receptive to that argument.
When they look down the ballot and see the alternatives, they get receptive in a hurry.
Was there anything else, or can I sit here now?
[standing to leave] You can sit here. I'll see you tomorrow.
Yeah.
Sam, I'm looking at opposition polling that scares the hell out of me. I'm looking at internal numbers that change by the hour. I'm listening to economists who tell me there's weather...
You left me out.
[sighing] Yeah.
You think I'm the reason you got beat on the Leadership Breakfast?
I got creamed, Sam.
You think I'm the reason?
I don't want that discussion.

Then what are you doing here talking to me? Now you want the discussion. You and the president may think they deserved it, but this cynicism of attacking your friends for political protection offends them and it offends me. It offends you, and there's really nothing I can do to make you feel better about that.
We can't govern if we don't win.
You should've talked to me about the numbers more.
Anyway. I have this beer...
Yeah.
I was just gonna sit down and drink it.
Yeah.
I mean, we don't have to talk or anything.
Yeah. Toby and Sam sit in silence.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Bartlet walks in and speaks to Leo and Josh, who are waiting for him.

Dialogues.Line: That was Chairwoman Shelly Lubis I just got off the phone with. Before that was a conference call with Jamie Schwartz of the Environmental Defense Fund, Bryce Davis of the Sierra Club, and three Democratic Congressman from the Subcommittee on Energy and the Environment. The number of different words they had for "manipulative," Leo, there's no way they didn't have a thesaurus open in front of them. Bryce Davis said if I keep this up, he's going to encourage Seth Gillette in a thirdparty bid.
What'd you say?
I said for fifty bucks and a ride to the airport, Gillette could have the job right now.
What'd you say?

I politely reminded him that it's probably not a good idea to threaten the president. [yelling] Nancy! [to Leo] I want to know when you're pushing me towards the missile shield it's not because you want me to look strong on defense.
Yes, sir?
Would you tell Charlie I'm ready?
Yes, sir.
I'm not. I'm pushing you to the missile defense shield cause I think it works.
Based on what?
Confidence. And the understanding that there's been a time in the evolution of everything that works when it didn't work.
You know, can I say this? Why don't we just give the sixty billion dollars to North Korea in exchange for not bombing us?
It's almost hard to believe that you're not on the National Security Council.
I know. I feel like they're missing an important voice. The door opens. Lord Marbury enters with entourage.
Good evening!
John! Let me explain why you've been waiting. I have to see people in the order they arrive, and you got beat by Argentina.
Oh, uhh... Well, yes.
You also lost out on preferred seating for the State of the Union.
I'm required to attend the State of the Union?
Yes!
Then attend it I shall.
Okay, Tom?

Mr. President, it is with pleasure I present His Excellency, Lord John Marbury of Great Britain, and by request of the Secretary of State, ask that you accept his credentials from Her Royal Majesty, Queen Elizabeth II, as Great Britain's Ambassador to the United States. Bartlet takes the folder from Marbury.
Where are you on the missile shield?
Well, I think it's dangerous, illegal... fiscally irresponsible, technologically unsound, and a threat to all people everywhere.
Leo?
I think the world invented a nuclear weapon. I think the world owes it to itself to see if it can't invent something that would make it irrelevant.

Well, that's the right sentiment, certainly a credible one from a man who's fought in a war. You think you can make it stop? Well, you can't. We build a shield, and somebody will build a better missile.

Well, it's a discussion for serious men. They say a statesman is a politician who's been dead for fifteen years. I'd like us to be statesmen while we're still alive. Lord Marbury, I accept your letter of credence from Queen Elizabeth, and, by affixing my signature and seal, do hereby declare you to be Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary. They shake hands.
Well, thank you, sir. Marbury turns and shakes hands with Leo.
Congratulations.
God Bless America.
God Save the Queen.
Let's go. The photographers snap pictures of Bartlet and Marbury as they pose.

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: END TITLES.
